title: House ends death penalty debates | ABS-CBN News
text:
House ends death penalty debates RG Cruz, ABS-CBN News Posted at Feb 22 2017 09:06 PM 
Share 
MANILA - The House of Representatives on Wednesday ended plenary debates on House Bill 4727, the bill reimposing the death penalty, which moved the proposed measure a step closer to a vote. 
The debates were terminated after just 7 interpellators spanning 5 to 6 session days. 
The period of sponsorship and debate on the bill was ended upon a motion of Floor Leader Rimpy Bondoc. 
This was preceded by a long lull in the session that came after Dinagat Islands Rep. Kaka Bag-ao ended her own interpallation of the bill, where she sparred with Deputy Speaker Fredenil Castro on the floor. 
Lawmakers argued whether House rules were being followed with the move to terminate the plenary debates. 
In the end, Presiding Officer Deputy Speaker Sharon Garin adopted the position of Bondoc. 
Northern Samar Rep. Raul Daza, an anti-death penalty lawmaker, appealed Garin’s ruling, prompting Bondoc to move that this appeal be put to a vote. 
Bondoc, however, clarified that the motion is to adopt a substitute bill. 
Albay Rep. Edcel Lagman, who is against the death penalty, slammed efforts to railroad the bill in the lower chamber. He also questioned the vote, pointing out that no committee hearing has been called to approve a substitute bill and the chairman of the committee has no authority to amend the bill on his own. 
"We should not be railroading this measure although it is a retrogressive bill because the hallmark of a deliberative assembly…is to give free reign to debates, extensive debates, so that differing positions can be heard,” Lagman said. 
“There are still so many interpellators who are ready to interpellate, provided there is a quorum. With the circulation of the list of interpellators the House leadership is estoppel." 
Lagman said the amendments to the bill are invalid and possibly illegal because they do not have the concurrence of the House committee on justice, which he said did not have a meeting to effect the wholesale amendments. 
Garin insisted they are now in the period of voting in refusing to recognize Daza and Buhay party-list Rep. Lito Atienza who wanted to speak up. 
Garin also put the amendments to a vote despite the objections of Atienza and Daza. 
In a "viva voce" vote, the amendments were adopted. 
Bondoc said the majority already approved the adoption of the substitute bill. The session then adjourned.
